awd_titl_txt: Analysis of stochastic partial differential equations with multiple scales
awd_abstract_narration:
In the description of complex systems, both deterministic and stochastic, it is usually important to be able to have a simplified model of those systems, in order to make their analysis more approachable. Usually, such a simplification is realized by looking at a smaller number of factors that are considered more relevant for the evolution of the system and by neglecting other factors that are considered less relevant. However, such an approximation, that can be effective on some given time interval, is not effective on longer time scales and the neglected factors turn out to play a fundamental role in the description of the systems' behavior. This research will analyze a large class of equations used in these models. These are highly complex equations and an understanding of them is crucial for a deeper understanding of the main features of the model and for a better effectiveness in applications. This research will develop new methods and techniques ranging over many fields of mathematics. Education and training will also be a major part of the project.
 
The main goal of this research project is the analysis of limit theorems for stochastic partial differential equations having multiple scales. In particular, the PI will study some generalizations of the Smoluchowskii-Kramers approximation for systems with an infinite number of degrees of freedom and its long-time effects, as well as the validity of the averaging and the large deviation principle for some classes of stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs). Specifically, the PI will try to understand what happens in the regime where the noise is weak and almost white in space. Moreover, she will study the convergence of SPDEs defined on narrow channels or describing stochastic incompressible viscous fluids in the whole space to a new class of SPDEs defined on graphs and open books. These asymptotic results will be important not only to provide a simplified description of some relevant multi-scale SPDEs that arise e.g. in the study of molecular motors and fluid dynamics, but also because at the limit they provide new interesting mathematical objects that are worthy of investigation. What characterizes and unifies this approach to all of these asymptotic problems is the effort to understand how they all interplay and interact one with the other.

por.por_cntn:
When analyzing complex systems, it is important to be able to have a simplified description of them. Oftentimes, such a simplification is realized by considering a smaller number of factors that are considered more relevant to the understanding of those systems and by neglecting all those factors that are considered less relevant. However some factors that may appear less important at a certain time scale, turn out to play a crucial role at some longer time scale. Thus, it is fundamental  to understand correctly the interplay among multiple scales of complex systems in order to have more effective models.

During the period covered by the funding of this proposal, I have studied several asymptotic problems for  systems that are described by stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs) having multiple scales. Small stochastic and deterministic perturbations of a system, which have a negligible effect on a given time scale can become crucial on a longer time scale. Understanding such effects was the main goal of my research project. I have studied limit theorems in the framework of the theory of large deviation and metastability, various realizations of the  averaging principle, and small mass limits as in the Smoluchowski-Kramers approximation. What has characterized and unified my approach to all these asymptotic problems has been the effort to understand how they all interplay and interact one with the other.

I have collaborated on this project with several international experts in the field of stochastic analysis, stochastic processes and stochastic partial differential equations. As a result of these collaborations  have written seventeen papers that have appeared in some of the major journals in Probability and Analysis. I have worked on the study of the small-mass limit (known as the Smoluchowski-Kramers approximation) for some damped stochastic wave equations, whose damping term is state dependent, and for some stochastic wave equations subject to a magnetic field. I have also investigated the long-time stability of such an approximation and the interplay between the small-mass and the small-noise limit. Another direction of my research dealt with the study of the validity of a large deviation principle for some systems described by SPDEs, in the joint zero-limit of the intensity  and of the radius of correlation of the noise. These results applied both to the trajectories in finite time and to the invariant measures. Another direction of my research dealt with the introduction of new examples of SPDEs on graphs obtained as limits of SPDEs on standard two-dimensional domains, as a result of the validity of some averaging principles. To this purpose, I have also studied the validity of an averaging principle for slow-fast systems of SPDEs with time dependent coefficients, in the quasi-periodic case. Finally, I would like to mention my results on several problems related to optimal regularity and Schauder estimates for partial differential equations in infinite dimensional spaces.

This project was related to many branches of mathematics and to numerous applications in physics, biology, engineering, economics, and social sciences, and motivated the development of new mathematical tools and techniques that allowed to give a rigorous descrioption of the long-time effects caused by small perturbations. 

The educational objective of this proposal was to introduce more young researchers to the study of asymptotic problems for random processes and SPDEs. My aim was to pursue this objective by recruiting and training graduate students and postdocs, developing special topic courses where they could be introduced to the more recent developments in the field, and organizing meetings where they could find a venue for networking and publicizing their research. During the period funded by this grant I have mentored three graduate students at the University of Maryland and a postdoc. One of these students will graduate in January 2023.

I have been serving in the editorial board of several international journals in the broader field of Probability and Analysis and I have been a member of several scientific committees; among others, the scientific committee of the Seminar on Stochastic Processes and of the Scientific Advisory Committee at MSRI. I have lectured at national and international institutions and conferences on various aspects of the theory of SPDEs and stochastic analysis and in some cases I have been invited to be keynote speaker. I have taught mini-courses at some summer schools. I have been active in the organization of several conferences and workshops.
